message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Sound Statistical Model Checking for Probabilities and Expected Rewards
Paper Abstract: Abstract Statistical model checking estimates probabilities and expectations of interest in probabilistic system models by using random simulations. Its results come with statistical guarantees. However, many tools use unsound statistical methods that produce incorrect results more often than they claim. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive overview of tools and their correctness, as well as of sound methods available for estimating probabilities from the literature. For expected rewards, we investigate how to bound the path reward distribution to apply sound statistical methods for bounded distributions, of which we recommend the Dvoretzky-Kiefer-Wolfowitz inequality that has not been used in SMC so far. We prove that even reachability rewards can be bounded in theory, and formalise the concept of limit-PAC procedures for a practical solution. The modes SMC tool implements our methods and recommendations, which we use to experimentally confirm our results.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of probabilistic system models:

## Overview

A probabilistic model is a term used when referring specifically to probabilities in statistical contexts.(no content)Stochastic processes are widely used as mathematical models of systems and phenomena that appear to vary in a random manner.

## Key Types of Probabilistic System Models

**Graphical Models**: A graphical model or probabilistic graphical model (PGM) is a probabilistic model for which a graph expresses the conditional dependence structure between random variables.(no content)Two branches of graphical representations of distributions are commonly used: Bayesian networks and Markov random fields.

**Probabilistic Programming**: Probabilistic programming is a programming paradigm based on the declarative specification of probabilistic models, for which inference is performed automatically.(no content)It can be used to create systems that help make decisions in the face of uncertainty.

**Model Checking**: PRISM is a probabilistic model checker, a formal verification software tool for the modelling and analysis of systems that exhibit probabilistic behaviour.

## Applications

Stochastic processes have applications in many disciplines such as biology, chemistry, ecology, neuroscience, physics, image processing, signal processing, control theory, information theory, computer science, and telecommunications.(no content)Probabilistic reasoning has been used for a wide variety of tasks such as predicting stock prices, recommending movies, diagnosing computers, detecting cyber intrusions and image detection.

**Probabilistic Programming**: Probabilistic programming is a programming paradigm based on the declarative specification of probabilistic models, for which inference is performed automatically.(no content)It can be used to create systems that help make decisions in the face of uncertainty.

**Model Checking**: PRISM is a probabilistic model checker, a formal verification software tool for the modelling and analysis of systems that exhibit probabilistic behaviour.

## Applications

Stochastic processes have applications in many disciplines such as biology, chemistry, ecology, neuroscience, physics, image processing, signal processing, control theory, information theory, computer science, and telecommunications.(no content)Probabilistic reasoning has been used for a wide variety of tasks such as predicting stock prices, recommending movies, diagnosing computers, detecting cyber intrusions and image detection.

## Monte Carlo Simulation

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Monte Carlo simulations:

### Definition and Core Concept

Monte Carlo methods are a broad class of computational algorithms that rely on repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results.(no content)The underlying concept is to use randomness to solve problems that might be deterministic in principle.

### Origin of the Name

The name comes from the Monte Carlo Casino in Monaco, where the primary developer of the method, mathematician Stanisław Ulam, was inspired by his uncle's gambling habits.

### Main Applications

Monte Carlo methods are mainly used in three distinct problem classes: optimization, numerical integration, and generating draws from a probability distribution. Additionally, they can be used to model phenomena with significant uncertainty in inputs, such as calculating the risk of a nuclear power plant failure, and can provide approximate solutions to problems that are otherwise intractable or too complex to analyze mathematically.

### How It Works

The Monte Carlo method solves a problem by directly simulating the underlying (physical) process and then calculating the (average) result of the process.

### Historical Development

In the late 1940s, Stanisław Ulam invented the modern version of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo method while he was working on nuclear weapons projects at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.(no content)In the 1950s Monte Carlo methods were used at Los Alamos for the development of the hydrogen bomb, and became popularized in the fields of physics, physical chemistry, and operations research.

Links: [{"title":"Statistical model validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_model_validation"},{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Uppaal Model Checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uppaal_Model_Checker"},{"title":"List of model checking tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_model_checking_tools"},{"title":"PRISM model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PRISM_model_checker"},{"title":"Statistical model specification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_model_specification"},{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_testing"},{"title":"Regression validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_validation"},{"title":"Statistical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_model"},{"title":"Regression diagnostic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_diagnostic"}]

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about statistical model checking and related concepts:

## Model Checking Overview

In computer science, model checking or property checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification (also known as correctness).(no content)This is typically associated with hardware or software systems, where the specification contains liveness requirements (such as avoidance of livelock) as well as safety requirements (such as avoidance of states representing a system crash).

## Statistical Model-Based Testing

A related concept relevant to your query is statistical model-based testing. Test models realized with Markov chains can be understood as a usage model: it is referred to as Usage/Statistical Model Based Testing.(no content)Usage models, so Markov chains, are mainly constructed of 2 artifacts: the finite-state machine (FSM) which represents all possible usage scenario of the tested system and the Operational Profiles (OP) which qualify the FSM to represent how the system is or will be used statistically.

## Probabilistic Model Checking

For probabilistic systems, PRISM is a probabilistic model checker, a formal verification software tool for the modelling and analysis of systems that exhibit probabilistic behaviour.

The search results cover both traditional model checking and statistical approaches to model-based testing, which combine finite-state machines with probabilistic operational profiles for testing purposes.

Web search results for query: "Expected value"

Links: [{"title":"Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value"},{"title":"Expected value of including uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_of_including_uncertainty"},{"title":"Expected value (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Expectation value (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expectation_value_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Expected value of sample information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_of_sample_information"},{"title":"Expected commercial value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_commercial_value"},{"title":"Expected value of perfect information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_of_perfect_information"},{"title":"Expected return - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_return"},{"title":"Value at risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value_at_risk"},{"title":"Value of information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Value_of_information"}]

Here are the search results for "Expected value":

## Main Definition

The expected value of a random variable with a finite number of outcomes is a weighted average of all possible outcomes.(no content)In the case of a continuum of possible outcomes, the expectation is defined by integration.

## Key Concepts

The expected value can be interpreted as a weighted average of the possible outcome values, with weights given by their probabilities, and in the general case, the expected value takes into account the fact that some outcomes are more likely than others.

## Historical Background

The use of the letter E to denote "expected value" goes back to W. A. Whitworth in 1901, and the symbol has since become popular for English writers.

## Related Concepts

The search results also reveal several related terms in decision theory and finance:

- Expected value of perfect information (EVPI) is the price that one would be willing to pay in order to gain access to perfect information.
- The expected return on a financial investment is the expected value of its return (of the profit on the investment).
- Expected value of including uncertainty (EVIU) is a measure that quantifies the potential benefit of incorporating uncertainty into decision-making.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

Here are the search results for "Reachability analysis":

## Overview

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of local entities that communicate by exchanging messages.

## Reachability Graph

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.

## Key Challenges

One significant challenge in reachability analysis is the "state space explosion" problem. If the entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages with up to two in each direction, the number of global states in the reachability graph can reach 100 million.

## Applications and Tools

The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, but also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.(no content)A number of tools have been developed to automatically perform reachability analysis and model checking on the reachability graph.

## Related Contexts

Reachability analysis also appears in other domains:
- In graph theory, reachability refers to the ability to get from one vertex to another within a graph.
- Context-free language reachability is an algorithmic problem with applications in static program analysis, determining whether there exists a path through a graph where the concatenation of labels along the path is a string accepted by a grammar.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Dvoretzky-Kiefer-Wolfowitz inequality"

Links: [{"title":"Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz_inequality"},{"title":"Stochastic approximation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiefer-Wolfowitz_algorithm"},{"title":"Dvoretzky's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dvoretzky's_theorem"},{"title":"Markov's inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov's_inequality"},{"title":"Hölder's inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C3%B6lder's_inequality"},{"title":"Kolmogorov's inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov's_inequality"},{"title":"Sobolev inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sobolev_inequality"},{"title":"Hausdorff–Young inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hausdorff-Young_inequality"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Requests for comment/Kiefer.Wolfowitz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Requests_for_comment/Kiefer.Wolfowitz"},{"title":"Łojasiewicz inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%81ojasiewicz_inequality"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Dvoretzky-Kiefer-Wolfowitz inequality:

## Overview

The Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality (DKW inequality) provides a bound on the worst case distance of an empirically determined distribution function from its associated population distribution function.(no content)It is named after Aryeh Dvoretzky, Jack Kiefer, and Jacob Wolfowitz, who in 1956 proved the inequality.

## Statement

The inequality states that the probability of the maximum absolute deviation of the empirical distribution from the true distribution exceeding ε is bounded by 2e^(-2nε²) for every ε > 0.

## Historical Development

The original 1956 proof included an unspecified multiplicative constant C in front of the exponent. In 1990, Pascal Massart proved the inequality with the sharp constant C = 2, confirming a conjecture due to Birnbaum and McCarty.

## Significance

This strengthens the Glivenko–Cantelli theorem by quantifying the rate of convergence as n tends to infinity.(no content)It also estimates the tail probability of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic.(no content)The Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality is one method for generating CDF-based confidence bounds and producing a confidence band, which is sometimes called the Kolmogorov–Smirnov confidence band.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain approximation method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_approximation_method"},{"title":"Markov chain tree theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_tree_theorem"},{"title":"Quantum Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain mixing time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_mixing_time"},{"title":"Markov chain central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Markov Chains and Mixing Times - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_Chains_and_Mixing_Times"}]

## Markov Chain

Here's what I found about Markov chains:

### Definition
A Markov chain is a stochastic process describing a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.(no content)Informally, this may be thought of as, "What happens next depends only on the state of affairs now."

### Types
A discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC) is a chain that moves state at discrete time steps, while a continuous-time process is called a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC).

### History
Markov processes are named in honor of the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov.(no content)Andrey Markov studied Markov processes in the early 20th century, publishing his first paper on the topic in 1906.

### Applications
Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes and provide the basis for general stochastic simulation methods known as Markov chain Monte Carlo, which are used for simulating sampling from complex probability distributions.

### Key Property
While the system changes randomly, it is generally impossible to predict with certainty the state of a Markov chain at a given point in the future, however the statistical properties of the system's future can be predicted.

Markov processes are named in honor of the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov.(no content)Andrey Markov studied Markov processes in the early 20th century, publishing his first paper on the topic in 1906.

### Applications
Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes and provide the basis for general stochastic simulation methods known as Markov chain Monte Carlo, which are used for simulating sampling from complex probability distributions.

### Key Property
While the system changes randomly, it is generally impossible to predict with certainty the state of a Markov chain at a given point in the future, however the statistical properties of the system's future can be predicted.

Web search results for query: "Confidence interval statistics"

Links: [{"title":"Confidence interval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confidence_interval"},{"title":"Interval estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_estimation"},{"title":"Relative risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_risk"},{"title":"Point estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_estimation"},{"title":"Rule of three (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)"},{"title":"Pivotal quantity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pivotal_quantity"},{"title":"Confidence distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confidence_distribution"},{"title":"Prediction interval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prediction_interval"},{"title":"Binomial proportion confidence interval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_proportion_confidence_interval"}]

Here are the search results for **Confidence interval statistics**:

## Definition

A confidence interval (CI) is a range of values which is likely to contain the true value of an unknown statistical parameter, such as a population mean.(no content)Rather than reporting a single point estimate, a confidence interval provides a range, such as 2 to 4 hours, along with a specified confidence level, typically 95%.

## Understanding Confidence Levels

A common misconception about confidence intervals concerns their interpretation. The confidence level reflects the long-run reliability of the method used to generate the interval. In other words, if the same sampling procedure were repeated 100 times from the same population, approximately 95 of the resulting intervals would be expected to contain the true population mean.(no content)A 95% confidence level does not mean that for a given realized interval there is a 95% probability that the population parameter lies within the interval, that 95% of the sample data lie within the confidence interval, or that there is a 95% probability of the parameter estimate from a repeat of the experiment falling within the confidence interval computed from a given experiment.

## Applications

Confidence intervals are used to estimate the parameter of interest from a sampled data set, commonly the mean or standard deviation.(no content)There are multiple methods used to build a confidence interval; for a normal distribution with a known variance, one uses the z-table to create an interval where a confidence level of 100γ% can be obtained centered around the sample mean from a data set of n measurements.

I found the Wikipedia article on the Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality. Here's what it covers:

## Overview

The Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality (DKW inequality) provides a bound on the worst case distance of an empirically determined distribution function from its associated population distribution function.

## History

The inequality was proved in 1956 by Aryeh Dvoretzky, Jack Kiefer, and Jacob Wolfowitz.(no content)In 1990, Pascal Massart proved the inequality with the sharp constant C = 2, confirming a conjecture due to Birnbaum and McCarty.

## Key Properties

The Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality bounds the probability that the random function Fn differs from F by more than a given constant ε > 0 anywhere on the real line.(no content)This strengthens the Glivenko–Cantelli theorem by quantifying the rate of convergence as n tends to infinity.(no content)It also estimates the tail probability of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic.

## Applications

The Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality is one method for generating CDF-based confidence bounds and producing a confidence band, which is sometimes called the Kolmogorov–Smirnov confidence band.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Sound Statistical Model Checking for Probabilities and Expected Rewards". Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - This paper proposes new methods and recommendations for sound statistical model checking.

**Key Findings:**

The paper identifies and uses 7 main concepts and methods:

1. **Model checking** (method) - Uses existing model checking techniques as foundation
2. **Monte Carlo method** (method) - Uses random simulations for probability estimation
3. **Markov chain** (concept) - Uses Markov chains for modeling probabilistic systems
4. **Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality** (method) - **Proposes** using this as a novel application in SMC for bounding reward distributions
5. **Confidence interval** (concept) - Uses confidence intervals for statistical guarantees
6. **Reachability analysis** (method) - Uses reachability analysis for analyzing system states
7. **Expected value** (concept) - Uses expected value calculations for reward estimation

**Validation Status:** ✅ All validation checks passed successfully
- Paper type: contribution
- Total triples: 7
- Entity distribution: 4 methods, 3 concepts

The triples_output.json file has been successfully created and validated with all entities properly linked to their Wikipedia articles.
